ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Continuation of previous Chinese classes at Yale; increased emphasis on grammar, sentence structure, and reading
Chinese written, spoken, listening, reading, and grammar skills
Critical thinking, writing, speaking, oral presentation, and overall Chinese language skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Chinese classes at Yale have been, by far, the best thought-through and most engaging classes I have taken. The Professors genuinely care so much about student learning and clearly spend so much time investing in tailoring the content and structure of courses to maximize student attention. Even on zoom, Professor Liang ensured that every member of our class had ample opportunities to practice speaking, reading and listening.

The interactive, small-group class sessions were helpful to improve speaking and listening. Some homework assignments, however, felt like busy work that did not actually help me improve. The worksheets were just questions pulled directly from study guides and were not a meaningful way to use the grammar points. The final project non-Chinese elements like video editing take more time than actually writing the Chinese part of it, which was also true for the cooking video assignment. Having a tutor is a great way to practice speaking, but using the tutoring time to review sentences written for homework meant that we didn't actually have much time to practice authentic speaking, which seemed like a missed opportunity.
This course touched on extremely unique topics and was very well-organized. I appreciated that the professors always outlined the assignments clearly and well-ahead of time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was very well-adjusted to the COVID-19 pandemic. The class schedule and assessments were always very clearly outlined ahead of time and there were rarely any misunderstandings.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the course is a good next step in the process of learning Chinese.
Yes, take this course. The professors are amazing, and you wont regret it.

Yes. This class touches on very unique topics that truly deepen one's understanding of Chinese language and culture. The small and intimate setting of the course also allows every student to engage very easily during class. Moreover, at such a high level of Chinese, the students who are enrolled are truly very passionate about the class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: All classes were a live virtual format.
